headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Ed Bastain is Interviewed about the Airline Industry; Larry Hogan is Interviewed about the Presidential Race; Duncan Crabtree- Ireland is Interviewed about Actors Union Deal. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: ED BASTIAN, CEO, DELTA AIRLINES
utterances.sentences: Industry does is that we spend all of our time focused on safety. Safety is our highest priority. We do spend time looking at every single incident that occurs, what we can learn from it. There's full transparency around that. No question, there's been a lot of new people that have joined the aviation infrastructure, whether it's on our side as pilots and people working in the airports or air traffic controllers, and that experience factor has certainly caused maybe an increase --

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: That's kind of scary. It sounds like you're saying lack of experience in new employees.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: No, I'm saying there is - there is -- it's a fact that there is new employees -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Which means that we go extra and beyond -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: To make sure that we've got the controls out front of that, because we know that could be a cause for danger.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You know, we're sitting here eight days before a potential government shutdown. Sad to be reporting that again. But one of the things that happens, if you have a government shutdown, is air traffic controllers don't get trained. And we're short about 3,000 of them in this country.What would a shutdown mean for travelers?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Well, a shutdown for -- if there is a shutdown -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: And hopefully there won't be a shutdown -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Hopefully.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: All members of the aviation infrastructure come to work because they're - they're front line necessary employees. And so we'll continue to operate through that.Yes, no question about it, it would cause a delay in the hiring and the training of new air traffic controllers. Hopefully, it's going to be something that we can work through.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, you guys saw a surge. It was - it was deemed revenge spending on travel after the pandemic. But looking at the data now, airfares were down 13 percent in this September versus last. Are people's Delta flights going to get less expensive in the next couple of months?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Well, airfares have moderated a little bit. Remember what we're comparing it to was last year.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Where people just needed to go somewhere, anywhere, and you really didn't care what the price was. We're now into a more stable position. So, fares have stabilized. So, I wouldn't say fares are down meaningfully, but they - they're - they're more stable.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And they're going to stay here and not go further?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: I - I don't -- I think they're going - there's always bargains. You know, if you're a smart shopper, you can always find - find good - I know you are, you can find good prices on Delta at all times.But we're also seeing the continued strength of the demand set. We don't have any - I think this revenge travel that people talk about is going to go on for quite some time.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It's going to keep going?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Delta halted its flights to Tel Aviv when the war broke out. Last I've seen, November 21st is when they're going to start again. Is that still the plan?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: I - no, I -- I anticipate we'll be suspended for quite some time.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Quite some time.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What does that mean?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Well, it depends on what happens. You know, we're not going to go until it's - it's safe to travel into - into Tel Aviv. And while we've suspended for a period of time, while we're trying to figure out what's happening, it's a rolling delay, rolling suspense. But hopefully we'll be back in the first part of next year, but it really depends on what's happening.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You have quite a lens on the economy. Recession?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: I don't think so. I think it's been the most asked question for the last couple of years with all the free money and the easy - easy interest rates that have been out there.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: I think the -- our consumers broadly are doing reasonable well. No question on the lower earning side of the strata there is some real stress.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: But, for Delta, we're a full-service carrier. We have international. We have business. We have premium product. We have economy product. Those products in total are doing quite well.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What about how worried you at just rite large about where we are as a world? I was struck by Jamie Dimon's comments speaking about the war in Ukraine and then - and then he said this right after the war broke out between Israel and Hamas, and he said, "they may have far reaching impacts on energy, on food markets, global trade, geopolitical relationships." And then he said this, Ed, "this may be the most dangerous time the world has seen in decades."Do you agree with?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: I - well, we'll find out, right? I think it's no question that what we see happening in Israel, what we see happening in the Ukraine are certainly signs for concern. And I think it's a call for leadership in the world and it's a call for political leadership and unity. It's a call for business to stand behind and be accountable in terms of what we can do to make a difference. And it's not really a time to be talking about what interest rate policy or when the Fed's going to do next.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: It's to really focus on the existential risks that we see.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Existential. Yes, you're -

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely, we see it. And if you're in Europe particularly, you're surrounded by it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.Artificial intelligence. Every business leader is focused on it. Everyone's wondering what's going to happen. You've said there's a lot of risk if it's not done well. And you even said, "you can never get to the point where machines are making decisions and replacing human judgment." Is the risk to AI to our flights and planes and aviation more now than the potential upside?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: No. No. I will - I will never get on a plane unless there's two Delta pilots -- at least two Delta pilots on that plane.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Never?

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Never. And we certainly use technology to help our pilots, to help our ground staff, to help our people that manage the company, make better decisions. But you can never replace human judgment in a business like Delta.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Ed Bastian. Good to have you.

utterances.speaker: BASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Poppy.

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Well, Republican candidates trying to show they should replace the far and away primary frontrunner, Donald Trump, at last night's debate. Did they make any headway? Former Maryland Governor Larry Hogan joins us, was on the stage, maybe later, next.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Five Republican governors -- or five Republican hopefuls took the debate stage last night -- some of them were governors, I promise -- to pitch themselves as the best choice in 2024. But another Republican, who wasn't on that stage, released an ad on Tuesday. That Republican was not Donald Trump.Watch. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) LARRY HOGAN (R), FORMER GOVERNOR OF MARYLAND: Our allies question whether they should still trust us and our enemies question whether they should still fear us. They don't understand the strain of folks in our party that think it's OK what Putin is doing to Ukraine. I think we ought to provide support. We need to stand with our allies and secure peace through strength. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: You know, to that point, the most -- probably the biggest platform you can have is to run for president. Have you made a decision yet? You hadn't closed the door. Have you made a decision?

utterances.speaker: HOGAN
utterances.sentences: No, I haven't. It's not really something that I'm actively working towards. There's been a lot of talk about that possibility. A lot of people have encouraged me to consider it. But it's a long way off. I'm still hopeful that we can find a Republican that can rise up and potentially take the nomination away from Donald Trump. I think that would be good for the Republican Party and good for the country.I also think it's time that the Democrats convince Joe Biden that perhaps he should not seek a second term and let them find a new generation of Democrats. You know, 70 percent of the people in America are really frustrated and fed up. They do not want a rematch and they do not want Joe Biden or Donald Trump to be president. So, we're going to have to wait and see as this plays out. It's very, very early. These things change. We've -- once we get into the early states in January and February and by the time we get to Super Tuesday in March, we're going to kind of know exactly where we are. And if - if 70 some percent of the people don't want choice a or choice b, then there's a very serious possibility and opportunity to offer them choice c.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: So after Super Tuesday is when you will make a final decision on that?

utterances.speaker: HOGAN
utterances.sentences: I think the - they're waiting to see when they get past Super Tuesday, have some talk about putting together some kind of -- an effort to put a ticket together.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: OK. HOGAN

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Can I ask you, you know, in the wake -- the debate last night happened after Tuesday where Democrats had -- I think even Republicans would acknowledge - was a very good night. In fact, Republicans did acknowledge it on the stage.Take a listen. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) VIVEK RAMASWAMY (R), 2024 PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: And I am upset about what happened last night. We've become a party of losers at the end of the day. GOV. RON DESANTIS (R-FL), 2024 PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Got to do a better job on these referenda. I think of all the stuff that's happened to the pro-life cause, they have been caught flatfooted on these referenda and they have been losing the referenda. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: On the issue of abortion specifically, do you think your party is just in the wrong place on the policy right now?

utterances.speaker: HOGAN
utterances.sentences: I think they're completely out of touch with the voters and what the voters want to be talking about right now. And so it's the same case of, whether (ph) Democrats and Republicans, playing to their base, either in - to their far right base or their far left base, thinking that's going to fire up people at the base of their party, which it will. But it also turns off wide swaths of swing voters that we need to win elections. And - so, I think it's a mistake.I thought the entire policy in Virginia was poorly planned. I think Governor Youngkin set the bar very high, tried to make everyone in the country believe that he was going to pull off this big switch, taking over both houses of the legislature in Virginia and then that was going to - he was going to roll across the country and it was going to be a big -- he was going to show the rest of us how it's done. Well, he showed us. It was done really poorly. And not only did he not pick up a seat, you know, a body of the legislature, he lost the one that he had. And it couldn't have been a more terrible night for Virginia Republicans and Glenn Youngkin in particular.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Do you think Youngkin's political career is over?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Governor Larry Hogan, we appreciate your time. I should say, former Governor Larry Hogan. We appreciate your time. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HOGAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Well, after almost four months striking Hollywood actors reaching a tentative deal with major studios. So, when will production start up again? We're going to ask the union's executive director and chief negotiator, up next.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Back to work Hollywood.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Finally.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Finally. Action.(END VIDEO CLIP) (COMMERCIAL BREAK) (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Ah! Oh my God! Oh my God!Oh my God! Oh my God! Oh my God! Oh my God! Get - I like, literally, I can't believe - I can't believe I'm not - I can't -- I'm just alone for this. I am so happy. I am so happy. Oh my God! (INAUDIBLE) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I mean by far the video of the morning.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: That was pretty good.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: You know, Duncan, the studios said that they were giving you their best and final offer on Saturday. You guys finally clinched the agreement on Wednesday. What triggered - what was the final step? What - what was the last thing that needed to happen to actually get this across the finish line?CRABTREE-IRELAND: Well, on Saturday we just weren't quite there on AI actually to be - to be perfectly honest. I mean you -- you zeroed right in on it, that is one of the things in this negotiation that's been just essentially necessary. It couldn't be done without it. And I think we finally, you know, got the message across. And both sides were able to find that approach that met their needs but actually provided our members protection that our members needed. That's what it's all about.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Duncan, that sounds like a very diplomatic way of saying it wasn't their best and final offer and they came back with something else. CRABTREE-IRELANDto the deal after last Saturday. And I think, you know, whenever you're in a negotiation, you're signaling things to a side, you're trying to get them to understand where you're coming from. I think when they said that, what they meant was we are close to the end. But we - and we were close to the way it turned out, but AI was a key point that had to be pushed a little further to get across the finish line. And that happened yesterday.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK.CRABTREE-IRELAND: And once it did, we were all very happy to bring the strike to the end.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: What's the timeline, not to be a consumer here, but I am.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But he is.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Everyone's trying to figure out because there's been so much talk about a ticking clock, right? If the deal wasn't reached in this kind of time window right now, entire seasons were going to be lost, productions were going to be lost. How quickly do things get back up and running? Do you just snap the fingers and go or is there a process here?CRABTREE-IRELAND: Well, I wish it were that simple. It's not quite snap the fingers and go. But I do know that the studio and streamers have already brought back some of the crew and other people who had to be involved in pre-production activities. So, there are some projects that will start up fairly quickly. But there are also others that have a longer runway. But the fact is, starting immediately, starting now, everyone can get back to work and the prep process for those projects can begin. So, I think, as a consumer myself, and like you, we can all be excited to know that our favorite content is probably on its way back as soon as possible.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Phil is very excited about this I can tell.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Very excited.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We all are.Duncan Crabtree-Ireland, thanks very much. CRABTREE-IRELAND: Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, new recognition for recording artist Tacey Chapman and her classic fabulous song "Fast Car" with a little help from country artist Luke Combs.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And the CMA award for the Song of the Year goes to "Fast Car" Tracy Chapman. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Luke Combs, that is, of course, Luke Combs, also won a CMA for single of the year. In his acceptance speech Combs thanked Chapman for writing, quote, "one of the best songs of all time." Combs' cover has reached number one on the country air play chart. That also makes Chapman the first black woman to top the chart as a solo writer since it came into existence in 1990.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What's your Tracy Chapman song - like story? We all have one.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Like, all of us. It was like some - some bad moment or a breakup or something like that where you were like driving your car in high school.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Totally. Totally.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: That just got really personal really fast.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Like a breakup. Like, I'm never going to get over him, you know.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There is that.Did you see the hat Luke Combs was wearing?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: No, what was it?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, you didn't see it?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I saw it was a Vikings hat. I was hoping you didn't see it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Go Vikings. MATTINGLY

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: See, there it is.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There you go. Thank you, Luke Combs, but, thank you, Tracy Chapman, for your beautiful words all these years.Thanks for being with us.
